Shape representing a single or multiple segment line
(an “open” shape) with straight or curved segments
using
points within a sized container.
Lines default to being “flat” which prevents fill or
stroke from being auto-expanded via layer Addons.
See also OpenShape which behaves similar to Line
except it is NOT “flat” by default, thereby
supporting all Addons.
Map each relative Position of the current shape’s path
to another position or multiple positions. Return nil
to leave current position unchanged.
Return empty array to remove position, or array with one
or more new positions to replace the existing position.
Closure is passed a “PathStepper” which contains the
current position, the next position, the mid position
between current and next, and the current index in
addition to related functionality.
For more granular control see
IMPORTANT: positions provided by this mapper correspond
to the original target size of the shape, not necessarily
the shape’s final size. For example, with stock shapes
that draw outside the target size (e.g. a trapezoid that
projects outside the original rectangle) the positions
provided by this mapper may need adjusting for the larger size.
(Consider applying a debug ruler grid to help visualize
what the new relative positions might be.)
Map each relative Quadrantal of the current shape’s path
to another quadrantal or multiple quadrantals. Return nil
to leave current quadrantal unchanged.
Return empty array to remove quadrantal, or array with
one or more new quadrantals to replace the existing
quadrantal. Closure is passed a “PathStepper” which
contains the current quadrantal, the next quadrantal,
the mid quadrantal between current and next and the
current index in addition to related functionality.
Quadrantals support more granular control than Positions
including bezier control points, relative offsets
(positions only support absolute offsets), shifting
points and more—using visual operator syntax.
IMPORTANT: positions provided by this mapper correspond
to the original target size of the shape, not necessarily
the shape’s final size. For example, with stock shapes
that draw outside the target size (e.g. a trapezoid that
projects outside the original rectangle) the positions
provided by this mapper may need adjusting for the larger size.
(Consider applying a debug ruler grid to help visualize
what the new relative positions might be.)
